Linux Packages
If a package for your distribution is listed above, install that and then try using it! Otherwise, get the source package instead or try the generic binaries.
Arch Linux
Use the zeroinstall-injector AUR package.
Debian / Knoppix / Mint / Ubuntu
Zero Install is part of the main Debian archive, so you can get it with: # apt-get install zeroinstall-injector
Ubuntu 12.04 LTS: you may find a newer version works better: the Raring .deb works fine.
You may also install your distribution's version by clicking here.
Use on headless servers: If used on headless servers, the Debian packages above pull in a lot of GUI dependencies (~100 MB) which aren't needed. To avoid this, there is a PPA with separate core and GUI packages, which can be used as follows (on Debian and Ubuntu): apt-key adv --keyserver hkp://keyserver.ubuntu.com:80/ \ --recv FA7EE6962EA1EE2BC2BCF43BFA1C88090D3A39C1 echo "deb http://ppa.launchpad.net/tal-it-innovation/ppa/ubuntu precise main" \ >> /etc/apt/sources.list apt-get update apt-get install 0install-core --no-install-recommends
We have been trying to get Debian to use this version since Aug 2012. Current status (as of 2014-02-04): the package has made it to the NEW queue, but is stuck there waiting for further approval.
Fedora Packages are in Fedora (thanks to Michel Alexandre Salim), so just do: # yum install 0install for the new OCaml RPM, or: # yum install zeroinstall-injector for the older Python RPM .
Gentoo
zeroinstall-injector is in Gentoo (the version, 1.11, is very old though).

A package is available in the Fedora Extra Packages for Enterprise Linux (EPEL): # yum install zeroinstall-injector
Slackware
Slackware packages are available from slackbuilds.org (out-of-date).
Generic binaries
There are some pre-compiled generic binaries available. These work on Linux-x86 (32-bit Linux), Linux-x86_64 (64-bit Linux), and Linux-armv6l (Raspberry Pi with Raspbian).
Download the appropriate archive for your system, unpack it, and run the install.sh script inside. You'll need libcurl installed (most systems have it by default).
Fedora users may need to create a couple of symlinks to work around some incorrect library version numbers on their systems, e.g. (adjust "lib64" as necessary):
$ sudo ln -s libssl.so.10 /usr/lib64/libssl.so.1.0.0 $ sudo ln -s libcrypto.so.10 /usr/lib64/libcrypto.so.1.0.0
